discussion.content: To me, answer is indeed ‘D’

I concur with D as the Answer
----------
Explanation:
ios_vrf : Manage the collection of VRF definitions on Cisco IOS devices
purge : Instructs the module to consider the VRF definition absolute. It will remove any previously configured VRFs on the device.
Choice : Yes | No
Example: 
- name: configure set of VRFs and purge any others
 ios_vrf:
 vrfs:
 - red
 - blue
 - green
 purge: yes

Selected Answer: D
D is correct: 
- vrfs: The set of VRF definition objects to be configured on the remote IOS device. Ths list entries can either be the VRF name or a hash of VRF definitions and attributes. This argument is mutually exclusive with the name argument (string).
- state: Configures the state of the VRF definition as it relates to the device operational configuration. When set to present, the VRF should be configured in the device active configuration and when set to absent the VRF should not be in the device active configuration. Choices: Present (default) / absent
- purge: Instructs the module to consider the VRF definition absolute. It will remove any previously configured VRFs on the device. no (default) / yes

https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/collections/cisco/ios/ios_vrf_module.html

Selected Answer: D
purge 
boolean

Instructs the module to consider the VRF definition absolute. It will remove any previously configured VRFs on the device.

Choices:

no ← (default)

yes

https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/collections/cisco/ios/ios_vrf_module.html

choices.B: VRFs not defined in the host_vars file are added to the device, and any other VRFs on the device remain.
choices.A: VRFs not defined in the host_vars file are removed from the device.
choices.C: VRFs defined in the host_vars file are removed from the device.
choices.D: VRFs are added to the device from the host_vars file, and any other VRFs on the device are removed.

An application is being built to collect and display telemetry streaming data. Drag and drop the elements of this stack from the left onto the correct element functions on the right.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
virtualization platform: kibana
data collector: python application
data generator: ios-xe device
datastore: elasticsearch

Yes, Correct answer:
visualization platform: kibana
data collector: python application
data generator: ios-xe device
datastore: elasticsearch
Elasticsearch is a distributed search and analytics engine for all types of
data.
Kibana lets you visualize your Elasticsearch data. Do anything from
tracking query load to understanding the way requests flow through your
apps.

Given answer is correct
virtualization platform: kibana
data collector: python application
data generator: ios-xe device
datastore: elasticsearch

comments.content: what happens is that it is not "virtualization" it is "visualization"

discussion.content:
I think the best answer is:
virtualization platform: ios-xe device (IOx - Container)
data collector: kibana (will collect data from elasticsearch to show them as dashboards)
data generator: python application (will generate data from the device to send to a remote or local repo)
datastore: elasticsearch (will to store the generated data from the data generator)
https://aws.amazon.com/opensearch-service/the-elk-stack/

questions.question_text: Which transport protocol is used by gNMI?

discussion.content:
gRPC leverages standard HTTP/2 as its transport layer

https://datatracker.ietf.org/meeting/98/materials/slides-98-rtgwg-gnmi-intro-draft-openconfig-rtgwg-gnmi-spec-00

Option A

Explanation:
gNMI is gRPC network management protocol developed by Google. gNMI provides the mechanism to install, manipulate, and delete the configuration of network devices, and also to view operational data. The content provided through gNMI can be modeled using YANG. Built on top of gRPC - an open source framework developed by Google and managed by CNCF. RPC framework built on top of HTTP/2

Selected Answer: A
The correct answer is:

A. HTTP/2

Explanation: gNMI (gRPC Network Management Interface) is a protocol for network management, and it uses gRPC (Google Remote Procedure Call) as its underlying transport mechanism. gRPC itself operates over HTTP/2, which provides a number of advanced features over HTTP 1.1 such as multiplexing, flow control, header compression, and more. Therefore, indirectly, gNMI uses HTTP/2 as its transport protocol.

Selected Answer: A
Google Network Protocol = HTTP/2. They are the main driver behind HTTP/2
Agree, answer is 'A. HTTP/2'

Agree with "A".

https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/intro_inventory.html#organizing-host-and-group-variables

Selected Answer: A
Correct answer: A 

Generally speaking, this is not the best way to define variables that describe your system policy. Setting variables in the main inventory file is only a shorthand. See Organizing host and group variables for guidelines on storing variable values in individual files in the ‘host_vars’ directory.

https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/intro_inventory.html#organizing-host-and-group-variables

Selected Answer: A
*host_info = host_vars
Although you can store variables in the main inventory file, storing separate host and group variables files may help you organize your variable values more easily. Host and group variable files must use YAML syntax. Valid file extensions include ‘.yml’, ‘.yaml’, ‘.json’, or no file extension. See YAML Syntax if you are new to YAML.

https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/intro_inventory.html#splitting-out-vars

You can add group_vars/ and host_vars/ directories to your playbook directory. The ansible-playbook command looks for these directories in the current working directory by default. 

Since the questions is referring to the interface variables that are unique per device, I will go with host_vars. Also the question does not specify anything about grouping so group_vars is discarded.
host_vars directory is correct (A)

questions.question_text:
A developer needs to configure an environment to orchestrate and configure.
Which two tools should be used for each task? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: I agree with B & E

Selected Answer: BE
Duplicate.
Correct answers: B & E

Selected Answer: BE
"Orchestration tools
Ansible
NSO
Kubernetes (but this one is correct as well) 
Terraform

Configuration Tools
Ansible
Puppet
Chef
SaltStack 
SCCM

CI/DC Pipeline Orchestrators 
Jenkins 
Bamboo"

This is a classical Cisco screw-up question. And the fact that so many comments here plainly state that Ansible is not an orchestration tool is just one more reason to see how sometimes cisco does more damage than good to the market with its certifications. Ansible is both an orchestration and a configuration tool. Depends on how you use it (or maybe Cisco want's to take it up with Ansible's vendor, IBM: https://www.redhat.com/en/topics/automation/what-is-orchestration). 

The point is, such question shouldn't even exist as those definitions are largely based on each vendor's point of view. And although there might be consensus on what IS NOT configuration and what IS NOT orchestration, there is none on what they are, so really there is no correct answer here. 

Personally, I would say that all tools listed in this question are both orchestration and configuration tools.
This question is incorrect. It should be Ansible for configuration and Terraform for Orchestration.

comments.content: Indeed that is why the answer is B and E.
based on who's definition Ansible is not an orchestration tool? Cause their vendor seem to thing it is: https://www.redhat.com/en/topics/automation/what-is-orchestration).

Apologies, I made a mistake. The question is CORRECT. The only orchestration tool here is Terraform (B). Puppet and Ansible are NOT orchestration tools, they're configuration management tools so the correct answer is B and E.
I agree with san111 on this - this question is kinda garbage TBH because *technically* ansible and puppet and chef can do both items. But they said 'choose 2'
I think BE would be fine because, choosing ansible twice would be counted as one tool.

discussion.content:
I would go with DE
https://www.ansible.com/use-cases/orchestration
